facts.text: Plaintiff appellant is spiritual head or Mathadhipati of Lingayet Math known as Murusavirmath in Hubli Taluka, Dharwar district.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff appellant is the spiritual bead or Mathadhipati of a Lingayet Math known as Murusavirmath situated within Hubli Taluka in the district of Dharwar.

facts.text: On November 13, 1887, Gurusidhwaswami granted permanent lease of tract of land in R. No. 34 to Pradhanappa, rent Rs.50 per annum first six years, then Rs.25 annually.

anchor.surface_text: On November 13, 1887, Gurusidhwaswami, who was the then head of this religious institution, granted a permanent lease of a tract of land belonging to the Math and forming part of R. No. 34,

facts.text: On June 19, 1892, Pradhanappa sold portion of leasehold (Schedule 1b to plaint) to Bharamappa.

anchor.surface_text: in favour of one Pradhanappa and the rent agreed to be paid by the lessee was Rs. 50 per annum for the first six years and thereafter at the rate of Rs. 25 annually. On June 19,1892,

facts.text: In 1897 Gurusidhwaswami died and succeeded by Gangadhar Swami who accepted rents without repudiating lease.

anchor.surface_text: Pradhanappa sold a portion of the lease hold property, which is described in Schedule 1 b  to the plaint, to a person named Bharamappa. In 1897 Gurusidhwaswami died and was succeeded by his disciple Gangadhar Swami

facts.text: In April 1905, Schedule 1a land sold in execution against Pradhanappa's heirs to Kadayya, who sold to Bharamappa.

anchor.surface_text: who did number repudiate the permanent lease granted by his predecessor and went on accepting rents from the lessee in the same way as before. In April, 1905, another part of the land, which is described in Schedule 1 a  to the plaint,

facts.text: On April 8, 1910, Bharamappa gifted entire plots 1a and 1b to Dakshina Maharashtra Digambar Jain Sabha for building school for Jain students.

anchor.surface_text: was put up for sale in execution of a decree against Pradhanappas heirs and it was purchased by one Kadayya, and Kadayya in his turn sold the same to Bharamappa who had already purchased Schedule 1 b  plot by private purchase. On April 8, 1910,

facts.text: On August 31, 1920, Gangadhar Swami died, affairs managed by committee.

anchor.surface_text: Bharamappa made a gift of the entire premises companysisting of plots 1 a  and 1 b  to the Dakshina Maharashtra Digambar Jain Sabha, a registered body, for the purpose of building a school upon it for the education of Jain students. On August 31, 1920,

facts.text: On November 25, 1925, present plaintiff Gurusidhwaswami became head of Math.

anchor.surface_text: Gangadhar Swami died and for some time after his death the affairs of the Math were in the hands of a companymittee of management. On November 25, 1925, the present plaintiff Gurusidhwaswami became the head of the Math.

facts.text: On August 27, 1932, plaintiff instituted Suit No. 80 of 1932 against heirs of Bharamappa for possession, alleging no legal necessity for lease.

facts.text: Jain Sabha impleaded as defendant No. 23 under wrong name in 1932 suit.

anchor.surface_text: for granting the lease, the alienation was number binding on the Math and became void on the death of the last Mahant. The Jain Sabha was impleaded as defendant No. 23 in the suit, but under a wrong name.

facts.text: 1932 suit dismissed by trial judge, reversed by Bombay High Court on November 26, 1942, possession allowed except def 23 misdescription.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the trial judge but on appeal by the plaintiff to the High Court of Bombay, the trial companyrts judgment was reversed and the plaintiffs claim for khas possession was allowed in respect of the suit land against all the defendants with the exception of defendant No. 23

facts.text: Present suit commenced on 3rd December 1943 against respondent Jain Sabha for possession.

In order that a suit may have the benefit of section 10, it must be a suit against a person in whom the property has become vested in trust for any specific purpose or against his legal representatives or assigns, number being assigns for valuable companysideration.
